content: Drink more water. Hard, dry stools are a common cause of constipation, so the more water you add, the easier it will be to pass the stool. It’s especially important to drink more water when you increase the fiber in your diet. [1] Men should aim to drink at least 13 cups (3 liters) of fluid per day. Women should aim for at least 9 cups (2.2 liters) of fluid per day. [2] Avoid caffeinated and alcoholic beverages while you’re experiencing constipation. Caffeinated beverages like coffee and sodas, as well as alcohol, are diuretics. Diuretic dehydrate your body by causing fluid loss through increased urination. This may make constipation worse. [3] [4] Other fluids, such as juices, clear broths, and herbal teas are good sources of fluid. Avoid caffeinated teas. Pear and apple juices are mild natural laxatives. [5] [6] Eat more fiber. Fiber is a natural laxative. It increases the water content of your stool and helps bulk it up. This will help your bowel movement move more quickly and smoothly through your colon. [7] Abruptly changing your fiber intake can cause gas and bloating, so gradually increase your dietary fiber intake over a few meals. Experts recommend that you get at least 20 to 35 grams of dietary fiber each day. [8] Fiber can reduce how much of your medications your body absorbs. Take medication at least one hour before eating fiber or two hours afterward. [9] Some good choices for increasing your fiber intake include: [10] Berries and other fruits, especially those with an edible skin, such as apples and grapes. Dark, leafy green vegetables like collard, mustard, and beet greens, as well as Swiss chard. Other vegetables such as broccoli, spinach, carrots, cauliflower, brussel sprouts, artichokes and green beans. Beans and other legumes such as kidney, navy, garbanzo, pinto, lima, and white beans, as well as lentils and black-eyed peas. Whole, unprocessed grains. An easy rule of thumb is that if it is a light color or white, it has probably been processed. Go for whole grains such as brown rice, popcorn, steel-cut oats, and barley. If you are eating cereal, read the label to make sure your choice is high in fiber. Look for bread with whole-grain, unbleached, unenriched flour. [11] Seeds and nuts such as pumpkin, sesame, sunflower, or flax seeds, [12] as well as almonds, walnuts and pecans. Eat prunes. Prunes are high in fiber. They also contain sorbitol, a stool-loosening sugar that naturally helps relieve constipation. [13] Sorbitol is a mild colonic stimulant that helps reduce the transit time of stool and decreases the risk of constipation. If you don't like the wrinkly texture or unique taste of prunes, you can try prune juice. However, prune juice has less fiber than prunes. 100 grams of prunes have 14.7 grams of sorbitol. while 100 grams of prune juice has 6.1 grams of sorbitol. You will have to drink more prune juice to achieve the same health benefits, and you will also take in additional sugars. [14] Don’t go overboard with prune consumption. Prunes should start working within a few hours. It’s important to let one serving or glass of juice pass through your intestines before attempting to consume another, or you may risk diarrhea. Avoid cheese and dairy products. Cheese and dairy products usually contain lactose, which many people are very sensitive to. This lactose can cause gas, bloating, and constipation for some people. If you’re having trouble with constipation, cut cheese, milk, and most other dairy products out of your diet until you’re feeling better. The exception to this is yogurt, especially yogurt containing live probiotics. Yogurt that contains probiotics such as Bifidobacterium longum or Bifidobacterium animalis has been shown to promote more frequent and less painful stool passing. [15] [16] Consume bulking agents. There are several mild herbs that have a laxative effect and soften stool. These include psyllium, flaxseed, and fenugreek. You can often find these supplements in capsule, tablet, and powder form at health food stores and some pharmacies. Some may also be available as teas. Take these bulking agents with plenty of water. [17] Psyllium comes in many forms, including powder and caplets. It is also the active ingredient in commercial preparations such as Metamucil. [18] Psyllium may cause gas or cramping in some people. [19] Flaxseed is used for constipation and diarrhea. Flaxseed provides fiber and omega-3 fatty acids. You can stir flaxseeds into yogurt or cereals. [20] Flaxseed is not recommended for people who have bleeding disorders, intestinal obstructions, or high blood pressure. Do not take flaxseed if you are pregnant or breast-feeding. [21] Fenugreek is used for several digestive ailments, including upset stomach and constipation. [22] Fenugreek is likely unsafe to use if you are pregnant or breast-feeding. Do not give fenugreek to young children. [23] Take castor oil. When you are constipated, castor oil can help stimulate your intestines. It can also lubricate your bowels so the stool may slip out more easily. [24] Castor oil is generally considered safe. However, you should take only the recommended dosage. You should consult your doctor if you have appendicitis or intestinal blockage. Do not use castor oil if you are pregnant. [25] Castor oil can cause a variety of rare but unpleasant side effects if you take too much. An overdose of castor oil can cause abdominal cramps, dizziness, fainting, nausea, diarrhea, skin rash, shortness of breath, chest pain, and tightness in the throat. Contact Poison Control or your emergency medical services if you have taken too much castor oil. [26] Be aware that fish oil may cause constipation. Unless recommended by your doctor, do not take fish oil supplements for constipation. [27] [28] Take magnesium. Magnesium can be very effective in relieving constipation. It helps to draw water into the bowel and soften the stool so it can move through your intestines. [29] Consult with your doctor before taking magnesium supplements, as it can interact with medications such as antibiotics, muscle relaxants, and blood pressure medications. [30] In addition to dietary sources, such as broccoli and legumes, there are several other ways to take magnesium. You can take magnesium by adding a teaspoon (or 10-30 grams) of Epsom salt (magnesium sulfate) to 6-8 ounces of water. Mix well and drink. This mixture can taste unpleasant to some people. Magnesium citrate is available in tablets and oral suspensions. Take the recommended dosage as marked on the package (or as recommended by a doctor or pharmacist). Drink a full glass of water with each dose. [31] Magnesium hydroxide, also known as milk of magnesia, is also effective at treating constipation. Incorporate yogurt into your daily diet. Yogurt contains live bacterial cultures (probiotics) that create the right environment for your digestive system to stay healthy and run on a regular schedule. Try adding a cup of yogurt to your daily diet. [32] The bacteria in yogurt are thought to alter the microflora in the gut. This reduces the amount of time it takes for your food to be digested and move through your system. Check the label to make sure the yogurt you buy has “active cultures” of live bacteria. Without live cultures the yogurt will not have the same effect. Other fermented and cultured foods such as kombucha, kimchi and sauerkraut also contain beneficial bacteria that may aid in digestion and relieve constipation. [33] Avoid processed foods. Processed and “fast” foods can contribute to chronic constipation. These foods are often high in fat and low in fiber and do not offer much nutrition. Foods to stay away from include: [34] Processed or “enriched” grains. White bread, pastries, many pastas, and breakfast cereals often include flour that has been stripped of much of its fiber and nutritional value. Look for whole grains instead. Junk foods. Foods with a high level of fat and sugar can cause constipation. Your body will try to get its calories from fat first, which will slow digestion. [35] Sausage, red meat, and luncheon meats often contain a high level of fat and salt. Look for lean meats such as fish, chicken, and turkey. Potato chips, french fries, and similar foods do not offer much nutrition and have very little fiber. Go for roasted or baked sweet potato “fries” or air-popped popcorn instead. Get more exercise. A lack of exercise may cause weakness in your intestines, making it hard to pass waste regularly. Sedentary lifestyles can affect digestion and cause constipation. [36] Get moderate exercise at least 3-4 times a week. [37] Walking, swimming, jogging, and yoga are all great options. Even 10-15 minutes of exercise a day can help your body stay regular. Don’t ignore your body’s rhythms. Your body will tell you when it is ready to have a bowel movement. [38] There is a wide range of what is considered “normal” for bowel movement frequency. Many people average 1-2 bowel movements per day, but others may go only 3 times a week. As long as your body feels comfortable, there’s no need to worry about how often you have a bowel movement. [39] Constipation can be caused or aggravated by not having a bowel movement when you feel the need to. If you frequently delay your bowel movements, you could cause your body to stop sending the signal to go. Delaying a bowel movement will also make it more difficult to pass later. [40] [41] Avoid becoming reliant on laxatives. Overusing laxatives, especially stimulant laxatives, can cause your body to become dependent on them. Do not use laxatives every day. If you have chronic constipation, consult your physician for alternative treatments. [42] Laxatives containing polyethylene glycol are usually safer for long-term use than other types. [43] [44] Get some exercise. If you can, try taking hourly walk-breaks to "massage" your bowels. [45] Start out walking slowly for about 30 seconds. Gradually pick up the pace until you are walking as fast as you can without breaking into a run. Do the fast walk for about 5 minutes. Then, slow down for another 5 minutes. The total time spent walking should be about 10 minutes every hour or so. [46] If that amount of time doesn’t work for you because of other responsibilities, don’t worry. Just try to increase the amount of faster-than-normal walking you do whenever possible. If you are severely constipated, this may be somewhat uncomfortable, but try not to get discouraged. It's better than another day of constipation. Try a different position. Aboriginal people tend to have bowel movements while squatting, and this position can be helpful. [47] When you are on the toilet, use a stool or the edge of the bathtub to prop your feet up. [48] You want to bring your knees in as close to your chest as possible. This increases the pressure on your bowels and may ease the passage of a stool. Try yoga. There are several yoga poses you can try to help stimulate your bowel and get your body in a comfortable position to have a bowel movement. They can increase the internal pressure on your intestines and help the bowels move the stool more easily. [49] Among these are the following: Baddha Konasana: In a seated position, bend your knees and bring your feet together so the soles are touching, and grasp your toes with your hands. Flutter your legs quickly, then lean forward so that your forehead touches the floor. Hold for 5 to 10 breaths. Pavanamuktasana: In a reclined position, stretch your legs out in front of you. Bring one knee up to your chest, and hold it there with your hands. Pick one leg and pull your knee against your chest and flex or wiggle your toes. Hold that position for 5 to 10 breaths, then repeat with the other leg. Uttanasana: From a standing position, keep your legs straight and bend at the waist. Touch the mat with your hands or grasp the back of your legs. Hold for 5 to 10 breaths. Take mineral oil. Liquid mineral oil will coat your stool with an oily, waterproof film. This will help the stool retain moisture and move smoothly through your colon. [50] You can find mineral oil at most pharmacies and drug stores. Usually, it is combined with liquid, such as milk, juice, or water, to consume it. [51] Do not take mineral oil without first consulting a doctor if you have any of the following conditions: food or medication allergies, pregnancy, heart failure, appendicitis, trouble swallowing, stomach pain, nausea or vomiting, rectal bleeding, or kidney problems. [52] Do not take other laxatives or stool softeners at the same time as mineral oil unless instructed by your doctor. Do not give mineral oil to children younger than 6. Do not take mineral oil regularly. Regular use can cause dependency on its laxative effect. It can also keep your body from absorbing enough vitamins A, D, E, and K. [53] Do not take more than the recommended dosage of mineral oil. Overdose can cause severe side effects, including abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting. If you have taken more than the recommended dose, seek emergency medical assistance. [54] Try purgative herbs. For rare or severe constipation, there are stronger herbs that can help relieve constipation. They are usually not safe for prolonged consumption and should be considered a last resort after other treatments have not worked. Common herbal treatments include: [55] Sennosides are stimulant laxatives. They hydrate your intestines to help your bowel movements move smoothly. Natural senna laxatives can take 6-12 hours to work. They usually come in oral suspensions and tablets. [56] Talk with your doctor before using senna if you've recently had surgery, you already take laxatives every day, or you have any preexisting conditions involving your digestive system. [57] European buckthorn is sometimes used to treat constipation. It is only recommended for short-term use (less than 8-10 days). It can cause side effects such as cramps, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and heart problems. It should not be used if you are pregnant, breast-feeding, or under 12 years old. [58] Do not take European buckthorn if you have stomach pain or intestinal problems, such as appendicitis, Crohn’s disease IBS, or ulcerative colitis. Get care immediately if you have severe pain or blood in your stool. This can be a sign that you have a more serious condition than constipation, though you shouldn’t worry. Once your doctor determines the cause of your symptoms, they can recommend the right course of treatment. If you have any of the following symptoms, ask your doctor for a same-day appointment or visit an urgent care center: [59] Bleeding from your rectum Blood in your stool Persistent pain in your abdomen Bloating Problems passing gas Vomiting Lower back pain Fever See your doctor if you haven’t had a bowel movement in more than 3 days. You may need stronger laxatives that are available by prescription. Additionally, your doctor can rule out potential underlying conditions that may be causing your constipation. [60] Your doctor can offer you treatments that aren’t available over the counter. Laxatives usually start to work in about 2 days. Additionally, you shouldn’t take them for longer than a week. Visit your doctor for chronic constipation that doesn’t improve with self-care. If you’ve been experiencing constipation several days a week for at least 3 weeks, then it’s considered chronic. Your doctor can help you figure out why you’re constipated so often. Plus, they can offer you additional treatment options, like prescription laxatives, that can help you have better bowel movements. [61] Tell your doctor what type of diet and lifestyle changes you’ve made. They’ll likely recommend some different things you can try to help you relieve your constipation. Talk to your doctor if you have a family history of colon or rectal cancer. Getting constipated is a normal issue that will most likely go away if you make changes to your diet or lifestyle. Although you likely don’t have a serious health issue, it’s best to discuss your medical history with your doctor. They can help you recognize the signs of a serious condition so you can treat it early. [62] Your doctor will most likely recommend continuing your self-care regimen to relieve your constipation. However, it’s always better to be safe when it comes to your health.

	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Zora Degrandpre, ND</a>
</div>

Dr. Degrandpre is a licensed Naturopathic Physician in Washington. She received her ND from the National College of Natural Medicine in 2007.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">64 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Constipation can be frustrating and painful, but you can find relief with quick, natural home treatments. In most cases, constipation happens because you’re not eating enough fiber, are dehydrated, or aren’t getting enough exercise. Additionally, some medications can cause constipation. To relieve your constipation quickly and naturally, make diet and lifestyle changes to support healthy bowel movements. However, seek medical attention if you experience pain, bleeding or persistent constipation.</p>

<a class="anchor" name="Taking_Immediate_Action_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Taking_Immediate_Action">Taking Immediate Action</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-2-Version-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-2-Version-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-2-Version-6.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-2-Version-6.jpg" height="546" id="img_0b9b3d459c" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0b9b3d459c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-2-Version-6.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-2-Version-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Drink more water.</b> Hard, dry stools are a common cause of constipation, so the more water you add, the easier it will be to pass the stool. It’s especially important to drink more water when you increase the fiber in your diet.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Men should aim to drink at least 13 cups (3 liters) of fluid per day. Women should aim for at least 9 cups (2.2 liters) of fluid per day.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Avoid caffeinated and alcoholic beverages while you’re experiencing constipation. Caffeinated beverages like coffee and sodas, as well as alcohol, are diuretics. Diuretic dehydrate your body by causing fluid loss through increased urination. This may make constipation worse.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Other fluids, such as juices, clear broths, and herbal teas are good sources of fluid. Avoid caffeinated teas. Pear and apple juices are mild natural laxatives.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Eat more fiber.</b> Fiber is a natural laxative. It increases the water content of your stool and helps bulk it up. This will help your bowel movement move more quickly and smoothly through your colon.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup> Abruptly changing your fiber intake can cause gas and bloating, so gradually increase your dietary fiber intake over a few meals. Experts recommend that you get at least 20 to 35 grams of dietary fiber each day.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup><ul>
<li>Fiber can reduce how much of your medications your body absorbs. Take medication at least one hour before eating fiber or two hours afterward.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Some good choices for increasing your fiber intake include:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup><ul>
<li>Berries and other fruits, especially those with an edible skin, such as apples and grapes.</li>
<li>Dark, leafy green vegetables like collard, mustard, and beet greens, as well as Swiss chard.</li>
<li>Other vegetables such as broccoli, spinach, carrots, cauliflower, brussel sprouts, artichokes and green beans.</li>
<li>Beans and other legumes such as kidney, navy, garbanzo, pinto, lima, and white beans, as well as lentils and black-eyed peas.</li>
<li>Whole, unprocessed grains. An easy rule of thumb is that if it is a light color or white, it has probably been processed. Go for whole grains such as brown rice, popcorn, steel-cut oats, and barley. If you are eating cereal, read the label to make sure your choice is high in fiber. Look for bread with whole-grain, unbleached, unenriched flour.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Seeds and nuts such as pumpkin, sesame, sunflower, or flax seeds,<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup> as well as almonds, walnuts and pecans.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-3-Version-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-3-Version-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-3-Version-6.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-3-Version-6.jpg" height="546" id="img_2880e896a5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2880e896a5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-3-Version-6.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-3-Version-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Eat prunes.</b> Prunes are high in fiber. They also contain sorbitol, a stool-loosening sugar that naturally helps relieve constipation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Sorbitol is a mild colonic stimulant that helps reduce the transit time of stool and decreases the risk of constipation.

<ul>
<li>If you don't like the wrinkly texture or unique taste of prunes, you can try prune juice. However, prune juice has less fiber than prunes.</li>
<li>100 grams of prunes have 14.7 grams of sorbitol. while 100 grams of prune juice has 6.1 grams of sorbitol. You will have to drink more prune juice to achieve the same health benefits, and you will also take in additional sugars.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Don’t go overboard with prune consumption. Prunes should start working within a few hours. It’s important to let one serving or glass of juice pass through your intestines before attempting to consume another, or you may risk diarrhea.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-4-Version-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-4-Version-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-4-Version-6.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-4-Version-6.jpg" height="546" id="img_8c8c66543b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8c8c66543b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-4-Version-6.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-4-Version-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid cheese and dairy products.</b> Cheese and dairy products usually contain lactose, which many people are very sensitive to. This lactose can cause gas, bloating, and constipation for some people. If you’re having trouble with constipation, cut cheese, milk, and most other dairy products out of your diet until you’re feeling better.

<ul>
<li>The exception to this is yogurt, especially yogurt containing live probiotics. Yogurt that contains probiotics such as <i>Bifidobacterium longum</i> or <i>Bifidobacterium animalis</i> has been shown to promote more frequent and less painful stool passing.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-5-Version-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-5-Version-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-5-Version-6.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-5-Version-6.jpg" height="546" id="img_3bf77f144c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3bf77f144c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-5-Version-6.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-5-Version-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consume bulking agents.</b> There are several mild herbs that have a laxative effect and soften stool. These include psyllium, flaxseed, and fenugreek. You can often find these supplements in capsule, tablet, and powder form at health food stores and some pharmacies. Some may also be available as teas. Take these bulking agents with plenty of water.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Psyllium comes in many forms, including powder and caplets. It is also the active ingredient in commercial preparations such as Metamucil. <sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup> Psyllium may cause gas or cramping in some people.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Flaxseed is used for constipation and diarrhea. Flaxseed provides fiber and omega-3 fatty acids. You can stir flaxseeds into yogurt or cereals.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Flaxseed is not recommended for people who have bleeding disorders, intestinal obstructions, or high blood pressure. Do not take flaxseed if you are pregnant or breast-feeding.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 21" class="reference" id="_ref-21"><a href="#_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>
<a href="/Make-Fenugreek-Tea" title="Make Fenugreek Tea">Fenugreek</a> is used for several digestive ailments, including upset stomach and constipation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 22" class="reference" id="_ref-22"><a href="#_note-22">[22]</a></sup> Fenugreek is likely unsafe to use if you are pregnant or breast-feeding. Do not give fenugreek to young children.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 23" class="reference" id="_ref-23"><a href="#_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-6-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-6-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-6-Version-5.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-6-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_68902940f5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_68902940f5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-6-Version-5.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-6-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take castor oil.</b> When you are constipated, castor oil can help stimulate your intestines. It can also lubricate your bowels so the stool may slip out more easily.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 24" class="reference" id="_ref-24"><a href="#_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Castor oil is generally considered safe. However, you should take only the recommended dosage. You should consult your doctor if you have appendicitis or intestinal blockage. Do not use castor oil if you are pregnant.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 25" class="reference" id="_ref-25"><a href="#_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Castor oil can cause a variety of rare but unpleasant side effects if you take too much. An overdose of castor oil can cause abdominal cramps, dizziness, fainting, nausea, diarrhea, skin rash, shortness of breath, chest pain, and tightness in the throat. Contact Poison Control or your emergency medical services if you have taken too much castor oil.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 26" class="reference" id="_ref-26"><a href="#_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Be aware that fish oil may <i>cause</i> constipation. Unless recommended by your doctor, do not take fish oil supplements for constipation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 27" class="reference" id="_ref-27"><a href="#_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 28" class="reference" id="_ref-28"><a href="#_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-7-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-7-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-7-Version-4.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-7-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_9337711c32" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9337711c32')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-7-Version-4.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-7-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take magnesium.</b> Magnesium can be very effective in relieving constipation. It helps to draw water into the bowel and soften the stool so it can move through your intestines.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 29" class="reference" id="_ref-29"><a href="#_note-29">[29]</a></sup> Consult with your doctor before taking magnesium supplements, as it can interact with medications such as antibiotics, muscle relaxants, and blood pressure medications.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 30" class="reference" id="_ref-30"><a href="#_note-30">[30]</a></sup> In addition to dietary sources, such as broccoli and legumes, there are several other ways to take magnesium.

<ul>
<li>You can take magnesium by adding a teaspoon (or 10-30 grams) of Epsom salt (magnesium sulfate) to 6-8 ounces of water. Mix well and drink. This mixture can taste unpleasant to some people.</li>
<li>Magnesium citrate is available in tablets and oral suspensions. Take the recommended dosage as marked on the package (or as recommended by a doctor or pharmacist). Drink a full glass of water with each dose.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 31" class="reference" id="_ref-31"><a href="#_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Magnesium hydroxide, also known as milk of magnesia, is also effective at treating constipation.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Making_Long-Term_Lifestyle_Changes_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Making_Long-Term_Lifestyle_Changes">Making Long-Term Lifestyle Changes</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-14-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-14-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-14-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_b8a181ce9e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b8a181ce9e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-14-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Incorporate yogurt into your daily diet.</b> Yogurt contains live bacterial cultures (probiotics) that create the right environment for your digestive system to stay healthy and run on a regular schedule. Try adding a cup of yogurt to your daily diet.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 32" class="reference" id="_ref-32"><a href="#_note-32">[32]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>The bacteria in yogurt are thought to alter the microflora in the gut. This reduces the amount of time it takes for your food to be digested and move through your system.</li>
<li>Check the label to make sure the yogurt you buy has “active cultures” of live bacteria. Without live cultures the yogurt will not have the same effect.</li>
<li>Other fermented and cultured foods such as kombucha, kimchi and sauerkraut also contain beneficial bacteria that may aid in digestion and relieve constipation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 33" class="reference" id="_ref-33"><a href="#_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-15-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-15-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-15-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-15-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_7fc699bc9d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7fc699bc9d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-15-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-15-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid processed foods.</b> Processed and “fast” foods can contribute to chronic constipation. These foods are often high in fat and low in fiber and do not offer much nutrition. Foods to stay away from include:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 34" class="reference" id="_ref-34"><a href="#_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Processed or “enriched” grains. White bread, pastries, many pastas, and breakfast cereals often include flour that has been stripped of much of its fiber and nutritional value. Look for whole grains instead.</li>
<li>Junk foods. Foods with a high level of fat and sugar can cause constipation. Your body will try to get its calories from fat first, which will slow digestion.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 35" class="reference" id="_ref-35"><a href="#_note-35">[35]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Sausage, red meat, and luncheon meats often contain a high level of fat and salt. Look for lean meats such as fish, chicken, and turkey.</li>
<li>Potato chips, french fries, and similar foods do not offer much nutrition and have very little fiber. Go for roasted or baked sweet potato “fries” or air-popped popcorn instead.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-16-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-16-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-16-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-16-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_aff691dff5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_aff691dff5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-16-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-16-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get more exercise.</b> A lack of exercise may cause weakness in your intestines, making it hard to pass waste regularly. Sedentary lifestyles can affect digestion and cause constipation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 36" class="reference" id="_ref-36"><a href="#_note-36">[36]</a></sup> Get moderate exercise at least 3-4 times a week.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 37" class="reference" id="_ref-37"><a href="#_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Walking, swimming, jogging, and yoga are all great options. Even 10-15 minutes of exercise a day can help your body stay regular.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-17-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-17-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-17-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-17-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_de67753087" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_de67753087')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-17-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-17-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Don’t ignore your body’s rhythms.</b> Your body will tell you when it is ready to have a bowel movement.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 38" class="reference" id="_ref-38"><a href="#_note-38">[38]</a></sup> There is a wide range of what is considered “normal” for bowel movement frequency. Many people average 1-2 bowel movements per day, but others may go only 3 times a week. As long as your body feels comfortable, there’s no need to worry about how often you have a bowel movement.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 39" class="reference" id="_ref-39"><a href="#_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Constipation can be caused or aggravated by not having a bowel movement when you feel the need to. If you frequently delay your bowel movements, you could cause your body to stop sending the signal to go. Delaying a bowel movement will also make it more difficult to pass later.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 40" class="reference" id="_ref-40"><a href="#_note-40">[40]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 41" class="reference" id="_ref-41"><a href="#_note-41">[41]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-18-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-18-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-18-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-18-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_d309d3b737" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d309d3b737')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-18-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-18-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid becoming reliant on laxatives.</b> Overusing laxatives, especially stimulant laxatives, can cause your body to become dependent on them. Do not use laxatives every day. If you have chronic constipation, consult your physician for alternative treatments.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 42" class="reference" id="_ref-42"><a href="#_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Laxatives containing polyethylene glycol are usually safer for long-term use than other types.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 43" class="reference" id="_ref-43"><a href="#_note-43">[43]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 44" class="reference" id="_ref-44"><a href="#_note-44">[44]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Trying_Other_Options_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Trying_Other_Options">Trying Other Options</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-8-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-8-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_a5ea5fac40" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a5ea5fac40')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get some exercise.</b> If you can, try taking hourly walk-breaks to "massage" your bowels.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 45" class="reference" id="_ref-45"><a href="#_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Start out walking slowly for about 30 seconds. Gradually pick up the pace until you are walking as fast as you can without breaking into a run.</li>
<li>Do the fast walk for about 5 minutes. Then, slow down for another 5 minutes. The total time spent walking should be about 10 minutes every hour or so.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 46" class="reference" id="_ref-46"><a href="#_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>If that amount of time doesn’t work for you because of other responsibilities, don’t worry. Just try to increase the amount of faster-than-normal walking you do whenever possible.</li>
<li>If you are severely constipated, this may be somewhat uncomfortable, but try not to get discouraged. It's better than another day of constipation.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-9-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-9-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-9-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_8a69b323ad" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8a69b323ad')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-9-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try a different position.</b> Aboriginal people tend to have bowel movements while squatting, and this position can be helpful.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 47" class="reference" id="_ref-47"><a href="#_note-47">[47]</a></sup> When you are on the toilet, use a stool or the edge of the bathtub to prop your feet up.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 48" class="reference" id="_ref-48"><a href="#_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>You want to bring your knees in as close to your chest as possible. This increases the pressure on your bowels and may ease the passage of a stool.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-10-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-10-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-10-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_ee81720714" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ee81720714')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-10-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try yoga.</b> There are several yoga poses you can try to help stimulate your bowel and get your body in a comfortable position to have a bowel movement. They can increase the internal pressure on your intestines and help the bowels move the stool more easily.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 49" class="reference" id="_ref-49"><a href="#_note-49">[49]</a></sup> Among these are the following:

<ul>
<li>Baddha Konasana: In a seated position, bend your knees and bring your feet together so the soles are touching, and grasp your toes with your hands. Flutter your legs quickly, then lean forward so that your forehead touches the floor. Hold for 5 to 10 breaths.</li>
<li>Pavanamuktasana: In a reclined position, stretch your legs out in front of you. Bring one knee up to your chest, and hold it there with your hands. Pick one leg and pull your knee against your chest and flex or wiggle your toes. Hold that position for 5 to 10 breaths, then repeat with the other leg.</li>
<li>Uttanasana: From a standing position, keep your legs straight and bend at the waist. Touch the mat with your hands or grasp the back of your legs. Hold for 5 to 10 breaths.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-11-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-11-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-11-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_0730727f99" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0730727f99')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-11-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take mineral oil.</b> Liquid mineral oil will coat your stool with an oily, waterproof film. This will help the stool retain moisture and move smoothly through your colon.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 50" class="reference" id="_ref-50"><a href="#_note-50">[50]</a></sup> You can find mineral oil at most pharmacies and drug stores. Usually, it is combined with liquid, such as milk, juice, or water, to consume it.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 51" class="reference" id="_ref-51"><a href="#_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Do <i>not</i> take mineral oil without first consulting a doctor if you have any of the following conditions: food or medication allergies, pregnancy, heart failure, appendicitis, trouble swallowing, stomach pain, nausea or vomiting, rectal bleeding, or kidney problems.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 52" class="reference" id="_ref-52"><a href="#_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Do not take other laxatives or stool softeners at the same time as mineral oil unless instructed by your doctor.</li>
<li>Do not give mineral oil to children younger than 6.</li>
<li>Do not take mineral oil regularly. Regular use can cause dependency on its laxative effect. It can also keep your body from absorbing enough vitamins A, D, E, and K.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 53" class="reference" id="_ref-53"><a href="#_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Do not take more than the recommended dosage of mineral oil. Overdose can cause severe side effects, including abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting. If you have taken more than the recommended dose, seek emergency medical assistance.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 54" class="reference" id="_ref-54"><a href="#_note-54">[54]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-12-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-12-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-12-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_2a0f527542" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2a0f527542')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-12-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try purgative herbs.</b> For rare or severe constipation, there are stronger herbs that can help relieve constipation. They are usually not safe for prolonged consumption and should be considered a last resort after other treatments have not worked. Common herbal treatments include:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 55" class="reference" id="_ref-55"><a href="#_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Sennosides are stimulant laxatives. They hydrate your intestines to help your bowel movements move smoothly. Natural senna laxatives can take 6-12 hours to work. They usually come in oral suspensions and tablets.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 56" class="reference" id="_ref-56"><a href="#_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Talk with your doctor before using senna if you've recently had surgery, you already take laxatives every day, or you have any preexisting conditions involving your digestive system.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 57" class="reference" id="_ref-57"><a href="#_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>European buckthorn is sometimes used to treat constipation. It is only recommended for short-term use (less than 8-10 days). It can cause side effects such as cramps, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and heart problems. It should not be used if you are pregnant, breast-feeding, or under 12 years old.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 58" class="reference" id="_ref-58"><a href="#_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Do not take European buckthorn if you have stomach pain or intestinal problems, such as appendicitis, Crohn’s disease IBS, or ulcerative colitis.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="When_to_Seek_Medical_Treatment_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>4</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="When_to_Seek_Medical_Treatment">When to Seek Medical Treatment</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get care immediately if you have severe pain or blood in your stool.</b> This can be a sign that you have a more serious condition than constipation, though you shouldn’t worry. Once your doctor determines the cause of your symptoms, they can recommend the right course of treatment. If you have any of the following symptoms, ask your doctor for a same-day appointment or visit an urgent care center:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 59" class="reference" id="_ref-59"><a href="#_note-59">[59]</a></sup><ul>
<li>Bleeding from your rectum</li>
<li>Blood in your stool</li>
<li>Persistent pain in your abdomen</li>
<li>Bloating</li>
<li>Problems passing gas</li>
<li>Vomiting</li>
<li>Lower back pain</li>
<li>Fever</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-13-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7359" href="#/Image:Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-13-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a1/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-13-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_4a4e1151d6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4a4e1151d6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Relieve Constipation Quickly and Naturally Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a1/Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid7359-v4-728px-Relieve-Constipation-Quickly-and-Naturally-Step-13-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">See your doctor if you haven’t had a bowel movement in more than 3 days.</b> You may need stronger laxatives that are available by prescription. Additionally, your doctor can rule out potential underlying conditions that may be causing your constipation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 60" class="reference" id="_ref-60"><a href="#_note-60">[60]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Your doctor can offer you treatments that aren’t available over the counter.</li>
<li>Laxatives usually start to work in about 2 days. Additionally, you shouldn’t take them for longer than a week.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Visit your doctor for chronic constipation that doesn’t improve with self-care.</b> If you’ve been experiencing constipation several days a week for at least 3 weeks, then it’s considered chronic. Your doctor can help you figure out why you’re constipated so often. Plus, they can offer you additional treatment options, like prescription laxatives, that can help you have better bowel movements.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 61" class="reference" id="_ref-61"><a href="#_note-61">[61]</a></sup><ul>
<li>Tell your doctor what type of diet and lifestyle changes you’ve made. They’ll likely recommend some different things you can try to help you relieve your constipation.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Talk to your doctor if you have a family history of colon or rectal cancer.</b> Getting constipated is a normal issue that will most likely go away if you make changes to your diet or lifestyle. Although you likely don’t have a serious health issue, it’s best to discuss your medical history with your doctor. They can help you recognize the signs of a serious condition so you can treat it early.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 62" class="reference" id="_ref-62"><a href="#_note-62">[62]</a></sup><ul>
<li>Your doctor will most likely recommend continuing your self-care regimen to relieve your constipation. However, it’s always better to be safe when it comes to your health.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="7359" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs qa_waittheresmore" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="20778" data-caid="21651" data-cqid="20795" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="47050" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105309" data-votes_down="67" data-votes_up="136">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can I insert a glycerin suppository once a week?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a><br/>
	Naturopathic Doctor
</div>
Dr. Degrandpre is a licensed Naturopathic Physician in Washington. She received her ND from the National College of Natural Medicine in 2007.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Naturopathic Doctor</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">No-- relying on a suppository is not a great idea. If your diet is rich in fiber and you are drinking enough water, there may be a concern that you feel you have to use a glycerin suppository regularly.  Make an appointment with your doctor and explain that you have chronic constipation.  Bring this article with you and let your physician know which of these methods you have tried. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>67</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>136</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="80422" data-caid="81295" data-cqid="80439" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="298787" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105309" data-votes_down="89" data-votes_up="135">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How long can I go with out having a stool?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a><br/>
	Naturopathic Doctor
</div>
Dr. Degrandpre is a licensed Naturopathic Physician in Washington. She received her ND from the National College of Natural Medicine in 2007.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Naturopathic Doctor</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Bowel movements vary from one person to the next.  For some people, having one or two bowel movements every day is normal.  For another person, having one bowel movement every other day may be normal.  Most people have at least 5-10 bowel movements a week or 1 or more a day. If you are not uncomfortable or feel bloated, then the number of bowel movements you have are normal for you. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="80423" data-caid="81296" data-cqid="80440" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="311291" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105309" data-votes_down="63" data-votes_up="91">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I have IBS and am constipated. What can I take?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a><br/>
	Naturopathic Doctor
</div>
Dr. Degrandpre is a licensed Naturopathic Physician in Washington. She received her ND from the National College of Natural Medicine in 2007.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Naturopathic Doctor</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Most people with IBS-C (IBS with constipation) benefit by mixing the approaches described in this article.  You have have to take an "all of the above" approach.  Also, keep a diet diary for a few weeks-- sometimes, certain foods or food combinations can make IBS-C worse.  The diet diary should help you figure this out.  Avoid foods with added sugars, fried foods, fatty foods or highly processed foods-- these tend to cause more constipation.  Include a quality probiotic and try some fermented foods (sauerkraut, kimchee or keffir). It is often a process of trial and error to find what works for you-- so try to be patient!</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>

<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>91</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="221815" data-caid="222688" data-cqid="221832" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1364959" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="22">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What can I do if I'm constipated and I have tried a suppository?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">

<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Try squatting, or go whenever the urge hits you. If you are in school or work and you feel the need to go, go. Holding it in will make it worse.</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="104004" data-caid="104877" data-cqid="104021" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="533271" data-submitter_id="2317248" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="7" data-votes_up="42">

<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I cannot poop without taking tea and breakfast. I want to change my habit and poop without taking tea and breakfast. What should I do? </div>
<div class="qa_answers">

<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(//graph.facebook.com/v2.2/1140762118/picture?type=square)"></div>

<div class="qa_user_label">Top Answerer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">A regular eating schedule is actually important for a regular bowel movement. If this works for you, it's not such a great idea to eliminate it if you do not have to.</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="125715" data-caid="126588" data-cqid="125732" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="417487" data-submitter_id="2317248" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="5" data-votes_up="29">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do I cure constipation as a child with only common foods and without cutting anything out?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_ta_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(//graph.facebook.com/v2.2/1140762118/picture?type=square)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:Heather-Kenyon-Haff">Heather Kenyon-Haff</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Top Answerer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Many children on a Western diet tend to be fiber-poor. Picky eaters tend to favor refined starches (pasta, white bread, crackers), and reject fruits and vegetables. There are some sneaky things to try. For instance, there are high-fiber pastas on the market. Try pureeing vegetables and putting them in familiar foods, such as mac and cheese, meatloaf, and lasagna, so-they can't pick the veggies out. And don't forget soluble fiber, such as Miralax, which can be mixed into milk, juice, even water, and has no taste or texture. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>5</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>29</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="36007" data-caid="36880" data-cqid="36024" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="196423" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="28" data-votes_up="90">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How can constipation be relieved in children?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Have the child drink plenty of water daily, such as one ounce of water per every pound of body weight. This can be accompanied by eating fruits and vegetables, such as watermelon, cucumbers, and ripe pears. Ground flax seeds can also be added to the child's favorite yogurt or cereal for extra fiber.</div>
